_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: If ammonia release is detected the security guard will sound the alarm for the entire facility.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Cascade Tissue does not act as primary responder to an emergency. In the event of an emergency involving the regulated aqueous ammonia, Cascade Tissue will notify the Eau Claire Fire Department HAZMAT team and the local private HAZMAT contractor, RESCO, for assistance. The emergency response plan includes a section for chemical releases under 40 CFR Part 68 and will be used for primary response and responsibilities by Cascade Tissue for notification and evacuation. In addition, Cascade Tissue participated in an exercise for emergency response for their regulated ammonia system with the Eau Claire Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Eau community emergency response plans as well as private HAZMAT contractors in the area and other fire departments to facilitate response to ammonia release from the facility and the responsibilities of all parties. In addition, other hazards were identified from Cascade although they are exempt from RMP.   

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Based on Cascade Tissue meeting with the Eau Claire Planning Committee, Fire Departments and private HAZMAT companies, Cascade Tissue will be updating their emergency response plan to improvements and procedures identified during the meeting. The review of the Process Hazard Analysis began on May 6, 2024 but has not been finalized.

2.	Hose and Gasket Leaks
a.	Pressure relief valve on top of tank if tank has a leak. 
b.	Locked coupling fitting prevents incorrect material unloading.
c.	Daily operator checks on Ammonia system to ensure no leaks (3x per day).

3.	Training 
a.	Maintenance & Operating personnel trained on procedures specific to aqueous ammonia. Operators have on the job training for 8 weeks.
b.	Operators and Maintenance personnel 
i.	On the job training
ii.	Work Instructions give specific step-by-step procedures for maintenance.
c.	All Plant employees given periodic Ammonia Awareness training and Emergency Response/Evacuation training.
d.	Meetings with Eau Claire Planning Committee and the Eau Claire Fire Department Hazardous Materials Team to ensure Cascade Tissue has adequate primary emergency response in the event there is a need for them to assist.

4.	Inspections
a.	Based on operations daily inspection, maintenance on equipment is completed as needed. 
5.	Emergency Response
a.	Emergency Action Plan
i.	Test notifications, response procedures, and evacuation procedures
ii.	Safety training on emergency evacuation and shelter-in-place procedures
iii.	Alarm tests for the mill from the Security Guard office.
These individual elements of the prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Records for all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility will be kept in the Environmental office. The following is a brief summary of accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPA's RMP rule during the past five years.
Accidental releases, as defined in 40 CFR 68.42(a), are those from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. Cascade Tissue has no reportable release in the last five (5) years.
For all incidents, non-repo

in on the north side of the property.
Cascade Tissue mill uses aqueous ammonia at greater than 20% ammonia concentration and exceeds the 20,000 lb threshold set forth in 40 CFR s. 68.130. Aqueous ammonia is identified as a toxic chemical having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the unlikely event of a substantial accidental release and is required to submit an RMP and an Off-site Consequence Analysis (OCA). 

Other chemicals stored on-site were evaluated and determined to be exempt from RMP requirements including:
	Flammables- Propane is not regulated as it is used as a fuel source on-site (1999 court decision). 

Cascade Tissue mill Program Level 2 accidental release prevention program and contingency planning efforts help effectively manage the hazards that are posed to the employees, the public, and the environment by the use of aqueous ammonia.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL 
SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

Cascade Tissue takes a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals. The management system addresses each of the key features of successful prevention programs including:
	Safety Information
	Hazard Review
	Operating Procedures
	Training
	Maintenance
	Compliance Audits
	Incident Investigations

As part of Cascade Tissue prevention efforts, the following prevention steps for aqueous ammonia has been implemented: 

1.	Aqueous Ammonia 
a.	Unloading procedure and training for Supervisor 
b.	Locked coupling for unloading - specific trained Supervisors with the key. 
c.	Supervisor checks all paperwork and ensures the correct material before unlocking the coupling for the tanker truck to unload. 
d.	Drivers have proper training and PPE. In the event of any release, the driver will notify the security guard at the guard house. Security will sound the alarms and notify the Emergency Coordinator.
e.	Tanker truck has two shutoff valves one on the back of the truck and on

Executive Summary

Cascade Tissue is committed to operating and maintaining all processes (especially those using hazardous substances) in a safe and responsible manner. Cascade Tissue uses a combination of accidental release prevention program (Program Level 2) and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment. The executive summary provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that have been designed and implemented and will be included in the RMP submittal. The following management activities include:
	A description of Cascade Tissue use of aqueous ammonia in the wastewater treatment plant at 29.9% ammonia, which is regulated by EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulation,
	An overview of the accidental release prevention program (Program Level 2),
	A five-year accident history for accidental releases of aqueous ammonia,
	An overview of the emergency response program,
	An overview of planned improvements at Cascade Tissue to help prevent accidental aqueous ammonia releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment,
	The certification of EPA's RMP rule and,

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Cascade Tissue operates a pulp and paper mill on-site, producing paper from recycled paper.   The mill uses recycled paper as raw material to produce the paper for various tissue products which is sold under private label. Part of the operation includes the use and storage of aqueous ammonia which is used as a nitrogen source for the wastewater treatment plant. In 1999, the facility converted to aqueous ammonia in place of the anhydrous ammonia, reducing the potential impact from an ammonia release.  

The mill is located east of the Chippewa River, in Eau Claire, Wisconsin. The location of the aqueous ammonia above storage tank (AST) is located near the wastewater treatment plan secondary aeration bas
